PARKS IS ELECTED
HULLABALOO EDITOR
Banquet Held By Juniors A
Southern
ATTENDANCE IS SMALL
Dean Berry And Hambleton
Are Present
• Once again we come to that time
of the year which is known as the
banquet season. The Juniors formally opened the season last Thursday night, by holding their banquet
at the Southern Hotel. This occasion
was quite different from the one
that they held last year at the "KitKat". Due to its formality and
tameness (compared to the '29 banquet) it was called a "gentleman's"
banquet.

TENTATIVE SCHEDULE
FOR EXAMS APPEARS
A tentative examination
schedule appeared last week
and copies can be found
posted on all the bulletin
boards. All students are expected to examine these sheets
for any conflicts which might
be caused in their schedules
and to report these to the Registrar's Office.
This must be done immediately so that the office will be
able to do away with all the
conflicts and issue a complete
and final schedule. It is expected that these will appear
on the scene some time during
the latter portion of this week.

LIBERAL CLUB HEARS
STEPHEN PODRABSZKY

Banquet Is Success

The arrangements, which were
made by Belmont Towbin and his
assistants, went off smoothly and the
affair, was termed a great success.
It is true that the class didn't turn
out in as large numbers as had been
hoped for, but those present enjoyed the funny anecdotes and
stories told by Dave Kaukman, who
acted as toastmaster and the
speeches of the other guests.
Among the distinguished guests
who were present were Dean Edward W. Berry and Waldo Hambleton, the coach of the Blue Jay
track team.

FRATERNITIES HOLD
BRIDGE TOURNAMENT
Continuing a policy which
was started a few years ago
and which has become a custom among the Hopkins fraternities, an interfraternity
bridge tournament is now being held. The contest started
last week and will continue
for a few weeks more.
As yet only a few of the
games have been played. The
A. T. 0. contingent defeated
the bridge fiends from the
Kappa Sigma fraternity and
are scheduled next to meet the
D. U. players. The Alpha Mu
Tau fraternity was defeated
by the Sigma Tau Deltas.

"The Alumni College idea is
growing throughout the country,"
reports Lafayette. The idea, which
was orignated last year at that institution, has received six new adherents, to wit: INIichigan, Columbia, and St. Stephen. The idea of
the movement is, it is explained, is
to keep the alumni better informed
as to the progress being made by the
college. Thus it is contended, can
the graduates be aroused to ,interest
in other collegiate things besides
football; and be of help in bettering
their alma mater.

EDITORIALS
FRESHMAN REGULATIONS
undergraduate

feeble protests of a small minority of the
Abody, the
freshman regulations were practically abolished at Hopkins
MID

one year ago. Today it is apparent that the tide has changed. The
present system meets nothing but criticism. Strange as it may seem it
is the freshman class that is complaining the most. The very ones who
were supposedly to benefit from this change are not satisfied. The men
of the Class of 1933 claim that they do not know one another and
that there is no class spirit.
The movement was designed to make the freshman feel less out of
place in his new surroundings. The result has been the exact opposite.
When regulations were in effect, the new men may have felt inferior
in the company of the upperclassmen, but they found many others in
a similar position. This year, however, the strange freshmen seemed
. to themselves inferior to everyone. Not knowing which men were
members of their own class, they felt more out of place than ever.
The protestations of certain upperclassmen to the effect that the
freshman is not put in his place except by the enforcement of regula'dons is not to be considered so seriously. Only a small minority of
the first year men need to be subjected to any such treatment as is
advocated. The majority upon arriving at college are anything but
too conceited.
In former years the class rush and athletic contests were a bright
spot in the undergraduate life. In the absence of any regulations these
were .naturally dropped. A resumption of such activities would certainly be desirable. In the first place, too small a number of under• graduates take part in athletics of any sort at the present time. Secondly,
the athletic coaches are given the opportunity to find varsity material
that otherwise would never be discovered. Lastly, more class spirit is
manifested on these occasions than at any other time during the year.
The re-establishment of a regulation compelling all freshmen to
attend football games in the cheering section would be an aid to the
• athletic teams. The lack of cheering during the recent football season
may be attributed to the eminently unsuccessful team. However, there
is no explanation for the puny cheering section that was on hand last
Saturday at the Army lacrosse game. That contest surely should have
brought much applause from Hopkins undergraduates. However, the
cheering was so weak that the attempts were quite comical.
Another regrettable feature of this reform is the passing of the old
custom of speaking to everyone met on the campus. This tradition
created a friendly spirit that is much to be desired.
The question as to what body should enforce freshman regulations
is rather complicated.. Regulation by the sophomore class is undesirable. The men who have successfully avoided paddling or other
punishments during their freshman year are invariably the ones who
most ardently punish the incoming class. Furthermore the second year
men are hardly unpredjudiced judges when holding paddles in their
• hands. This method of enforcement should only be adopted as a last
resource. Regulation by the Student Council would be advisable, but
• would require too great an addition of work for the members of that
body. A more expedient solution would seem to be the election of a
special committee. Such a committee, consisting of three or four members elected from each of the three upper classes, could give more time
and effort to• the enforcement of regulations. Serious offenses could
be brought to the attention of the Student Council while lesser misdemeanors could be punished by the committee. The undesirabilities
of regulation by the sophomore class could not thus exist.

The University of Maryland is
going to the dogs! In fact the situation is so bad that the office of U.
of M. dog catcher has been created.
Nominations for the office will be
considered -at the next meeting of
the Student Council. The winner
of this extremely desirable (?) position will be furnished by the university with all necessary equipment, including net and a Ford
truck, and a uniform of Maryland
colors, if desired. The reason given
for the existence of this situation
was that the local canines were
treated too kindly at the barracks
and fraternity houses.
Rutgers is the dryest of all the
universities covered by the college
prohibition poll, conducted by Pierre
s. du Pont., The Targum announces
Lafayette is wettest, with 80 per
cent of its students drinking, while
Princeton is a close second. Amherst, Assumption, Harvard and
Yale are also well within the stronghold of the wets. The results of a
poll taken in Barnard College, Columbia University, show that only
55 of the 312 women questioned
are in favor of prohibition enforcement.
The new uniforms adopted by
the government for the R. 0. T. C.
have caused a bit of comment in
the various college papers. Among
other things, the lapels of the coats
will be faced with blue and soft
overseas caps will be worn. If this
keeps up, the army uniforms will
become more gaudy than those of
the navy, if possible.

The telephone looks ahead
Even as you are putting through your daily
telephone calls, groups of Bell Telephone experts are calculating your telephone needs for
five years, ten years,twenty years from now.
It is their work to discover from all available facts—not fancies—how each state, city
and community will probably grow. These
facts are reduced to forecast charts, precisely
as an astronomer plots the course of a comet.

BELL SYSTEM

The Dutch treat system of dates
received a K. 0. at Rutgers, as a
result of a debate on the subject
held there last week. The debate
"Resolved: That all college dates
should be Dutch treats" was upheld
by the girls of the University. The

men took the negative side and won
by 57-21 decision of the audience.

Thus central offices are planned years before they are actually built. Underground
and overhead lines are laid out to fit future
as well as present needs. Expansior• of service is provided for.
Bell System planners virtually live in the
cities of the future. They play a vital part in
providing the best possible telephone service
for the least possible cost.

and is now in full swing. Usual
hostilities are existent between the
two lower classes, each of which is
endeavoring to outsmart the other.

suspend hostilities after six o'clock
of the evening of the other class's
banquet, and neither will they endeavor to break up each other's banquets.

PARKS IS ELECTED
HULLABALOO EDITOR
Banquet Held By Juniors A
Southern
ATTENDANCE IS SMALL
Dean Berry And Hambleton
Are Present
• Once again we come to that time
of the year which is known as the
banquet season. The Juniors formally opened the season last Thursday night, by holding their banquet
at the Southern Hotel. This occasion
was quite different from the one
that they held last year at the "KitKat". Due to its formality and
tameness (compared to the '29 banquet) it was called a "gentleman's"
banquet.

TENTATIVE SCHEDULE
FOR EXAMS APPEARS
A tentative examination
schedule appeared last week
and copies can be found
posted on all the bulletin
boards. All students are expected to examine these sheets
for any conflicts which might
be caused in their schedules
and to report these to the Registrar's Office.
This must be done immediately so that the office will be
able to do away with all the
conflicts and issue a complete
and final schedule. It is expected that these will appear
on the scene some time during
the latter portion of this week.

LIBERAL CLUB HEARS
STEPHEN PODRABSZKY

Banquet Is Success

The arrangements, which were
made by Belmont Towbin and his
assistants, went off smoothly and the
affair, was termed a great success.
It is true that the class didn't turn
out in as large numbers as had been
hoped for, but those present enjoyed the funny anecdotes and
stories told by Dave Kaukman, who
acted as toastmaster and the
speeches of the other guests.
Among the distinguished guests
who were present were Dean Edward W. Berry and Waldo Hambleton, the coach of the Blue Jay
track team.

BRIDGE TOURNAMENT
Continuing a policy which
was started a few years ago
and which has become a custom among the Hopkins fraternities, an interfraternity
bridge tournament is now being held. The contest started
last week and will continue
for a few weeks more.
As yet only a few of the
games have been played. The
A. T. 0. contingent defeated
the bridge fiends from the
Kappa Sigma fraternity and
are scheduled next to meet the
D. U. players. The Alpha Mu
Tau fraternity was defeated
by the Sigma Tau Deltas.

EDITORIALS
FRESHMAN REGULATIONS
undergraduate

feeble protests of a small minority of the
Abody, the
freshman regulations were practically abolished at Hopkins
MID

one year ago. Today it is apparent that the tide has changed. The
present system meets nothing but criticism. Strange as it may seem it
is the freshman class that is complaining the most. The very ones who
were supposedly to benefit from this change are not satisfied. The men
of the Class of 1933 claim that they do not know one another and
that there is no class spirit.
The movement was designed to make the freshman feel less out of
place in his new surroundings. The result has been the exact opposite.
When regulations were in effect, the new men may have felt inferior
in the company of the upperclassmen, but they found many others in
a similar position. This year, however, the strange freshmen seemed
. to themselves inferior to everyone. Not knowing which men were
members of their own class, they felt more out of place than ever.
The protestations of certain upperclassmen to the effect that the
freshman is not put in his place except by the enforcement of regula'dons is not to be considered so seriously. Only a small minority of
the first year men need to be subjected to any such treatment as is
advocated. The majority upon arriving at college are anything but
too conceited.
In former years the class rush and athletic contests were a bright
spot in the undergraduate life. In the absence of any regulations these
were .naturally dropped. A resumption of such activities would certainly be desirable. In the first place, too small a number of under• graduates take part in athletics of any sort at the present time. Secondly,
the athletic coaches are given the opportunity to find varsity material
that otherwise would never be discovered. Lastly, more class spirit is
manifested on these occasions than at any other time during the year.
The re-establishment of a regulation compelling all freshmen to
attend football games in the cheering section would be an aid to the
• athletic teams. The lack of cheering during the recent football season
may be attributed to the eminently unsuccessful team. However, there
is no explanation for the puny cheering section that was on hand last
Saturday at the Army lacrosse game. That contest surely should have
brought much applause from Hopkins undergraduates. However, the
cheering was so weak that the attempts were quite comical.
Another regrettable feature of this reform is the passing of the old
custom of speaking to everyone met on the campus. This tradition
created a friendly spirit that is much to be desired.
The question as to what body should enforce freshman regulations
is rather complicated.. Regulation by the sophomore class is undesirable. The men who have successfully avoided paddling or other
punishments during their freshman year are invariably the ones who
most ardently punish the incoming class. Furthermore the second year
men are hardly unpredjudiced judges when holding paddles in their
• hands. This method of enforcement should only be adopted as a last
resource. Regulation by the Student Council would be advisable, but
• would require too great an addition of work for the members of that
body. A more expedient solution would seem to be the election of a
special committee. Such a committee, consisting of three or four members elected from each of the three upper classes, could give more time
and effort to• the enforcement of regulations. Serious offenses could
be brought to the attention of the Student Council while lesser misdemeanors could be punished by the committee. The undesirabilities
of regulation by the sophomore class could not thus exist.

The University of Maryland is
going to the dogs! In fact the situation is so bad that the office of U.
of M. dog catcher has been created.
Nominations for the office will be
considered -at the next meeting of
the Student Council. The winner
of this extremely desirable (?) position will be furnished by the university with all necessary equipment, including net and a Ford
truck, and a uniform of Maryland
colors, if desired. The reason given
for the existence of this situation
was that the local canines were
treated too kindly at the barracks
and fraternity houses.
Rutgers is the dryest of all the
universities covered by the college
prohibition poll, conducted by Pierre
s. du Pont., The Targum announces
Lafayette is wettest, with 80 per
cent of its students drinking, while
Princeton is a close second. Amherst, Assumption, Harvard and
Yale are also well within the stronghold of the wets. The results of a
poll taken in Barnard College, Columbia University, show that only
55 of the 312 women questioned
are in favor of prohibition enforcement.
The new uniforms adopted by
the government for the R. 0. T. C.
have caused a bit of comment in
the various college papers. Among
other things, the lapels of the coats
will be faced with blue and soft
overseas caps will be worn. If this
keeps up, the army uniforms will
become more gaudy than those of
the navy, if possible.

The telephone looks ahead
Even as you are putting through your daily
telephone calls, groups of Bell Telephone experts are calculating your telephone needs for
five years, ten years,twenty years from now.
It is their work to discover from all available facts—not fancies—how each state, city
and community will probably grow. These
facts are reduced to forecast charts, precisely
as an astronomer plots the course of a comet.

men took the negative side and won
by 57-21 decision of the audience.
